bibl.title: Letter from Harvey Cushing to Howard A. Kelly, October 2, 1907

div1.p: Cushing writes about plans to speak at a meeting in support of Jennie Carroll.

div1.head: Letter from Harvey Cushing to Howard A. Kelly, October 2, 1907

opener.dateline:
DR. HARVEY CUSHING,
3 WEST FRANKLIN STREET.
BALTIMORE,
October 2nd, 1907.

div1.p:
I have just received your note with the copy of Mrs. Carroll's
letter. It is rather too bad that there are so many of them, but it is
quite possible that they may not all care to speak. It seems to me best
that we adhere to your original programme - namely, to have you. Dr.
Welch and Thayer give the more formal addresses, which ought to appear
subsequently in the Bulletin, and then at the close of the meeting it
could be said that there were many of Dr. Carroll's intimate Washington
friends who were present and who might be glad to participate. I think
we could write to each of these men, cordially urging them to be present,
at the same time letting them know just what the character of the meeting
is to be, adding that an opportunity will be given them to say a few
AC
C to Dr.
words in regard to Carroll if they feel disposed to do so. Do you think
they will understand and that they will not have their feelings hurt? I
don't think that any of these men are of sufficient national standing to
make the occasion as dignified as we would like to have it. Please let
me know if there is anything that you wish to have me do further.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, Harvey Cushing,
M.B. Dr. Howard A. Kelly,
1418 Eutaw Place,
Baltimore, Md.
